text: hey everybody thomas joseph here with
another kitchen conundrum for you a
thanksgiving conundrum are you in search
of a perfectly juicy bird with a crisp
golden skin well I have a trick for you
and you will have your Thanksgiving bird
on the table in a little over an hour
it's kind of an amazing thing and that
is spatchcocking a turkey so what is
spatchcocking well simply put it's
flattening out the turkey and what that
does is it helps the bird cook nice and
evenly and it gives you that wonderful
delicious skin that everybody loves so
to do this I'm just going to show you
take the bird flip it over and what
we're going to do is we're going to cut
out the backbone of the bird now if
you're intimidated by this step you can
certainly ask your butcher to do it for
you but it really doesn't take much
effort at all
so using a pair of kitchen shears I also
have a serrated knife which helps you're
going to follow along the backbone and
cut as close as you can to it all the
way through this is a very common thing
that people do with chickens and it's a
little bit easier because the chicken
backbone isn't as tough as a turkey but
if you are having problems with your
kitchen shears take a serrated knife and
this will make fast work of the job at
hand sawed down the back once the
backbone is removed you're gonna flip
the turkey back over the legs will fold
out and what you have to do now is you
have to break the breastbone to flatten
the turkey out and what that does is it
really helps the bird cook at a
wonderfully even rate there it is so it
flattens the turkey out slightly we're
gonna tuck the wings under just so that
the wing tips do not burn I'm going to
transfer it to a rimmed baking sheet
with a wire rack set on top of it and
this helps to collect all of those
wonderful juices as well as circulate
air underneath the turkey and this is a
twelve pound bird which fits nicely on a
rimmed baking sheet you really don't
want to go any bigger than a twelve
pound bird so I'm going to let this
turkey sit out for about thirty minutes
so it comes
not to room temperature but it's just
not so cold from the refrigerator which
will help it cook evenly it's been 30
minutes and now to season the turkey up
I have two tablespoons of extra-virgin
olive oil 1 tablespoon of kosher salt
you can eyeball it here and 1 teaspoon
of freshly ground black pepper slather
this mixture all over the exterior of
the bird and then make sure your oven is
preheated to 450 degrees the reason why
this presentation is so great the way
that this bird cooks the dark meat
pieces which you can see are kind of at
the exterior of the pan
typically take longer to cook as opposed
to the breast meat which is in the
center so the dark meat will cook at a
faster rate because it's on the outside
of the pan as opposed to the breast meat
which is insulated on the inside of the
pan so into the oven 450 degrees it's
been about an hour and 10 minutes
and our turkey is perfectly roasted so
it's half the time it's a really great
time-saver now if you really want to
shock your family you can put the bird
out on the platter just like this it is
kind of different
or you could carve it up just like you
would any traditional turkey I'm going
to try and lift it up hold onto the
platter
two wide spatulas really should do the
job so there you have it Thanksgiving
turkey in half the time with wonderfully
roasted breast meat and perfectly cooked
Ark meat I'm sure that you'll be cooking
your Thanksgiving turkeys just like this
from now on
enjoy
you
